questions.text: What is the ideal time between time of death & retrieval of eyes for eye donation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) <6 hours

 

Explanation:

 

The eyes have to be removed within 6 hours of death.

questions.text: Which among the following is the first country to establish a blindness control programme for the nation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) India

 

Explanation:

 

India was the first country in the world to launch the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in the year 1976.

 

Ref: Pg 480/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of blindness according to NPCB?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cataract

 

Cataract continues to be the single largest cause of blindness in india.

 

Main causes of blindness:

 

  • Cataract (62.6%)
  • Refractive Error (19.70%)
  • Corneal Blindness (0.90%)
  • Glaucoma (5.80%)
  • Surgical Complication (1.20%)
  • Posterior Capsular Opacification (0.90%)
  • Posterior Segment Disorder (4.70%)
  • Others (4.19%)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cataract is the commonest cause of blindness in India according to NPCB.

 

Ref: pg 483/  systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

Evaluate and distribute eye tissue for transplantation
Use donor eyes for research and education

questions.text: What is the function of an Eye Bank?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

  • Promotion of eye donation.

  • Registration & collection of donated eyes.

  • Receiving & preservation of donor eyes.

  • Distribution & research activities.

 

Ref: pg 487/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

choices.text: Cornea along with 3mm of adjacent sclera
Whole eye ball with a portion of the optic nerve
Whole eye ball along with surrounding orbital fat, muscles and nerves

questions.text: Enucleation for donor eye retrieval involves gathering which all components?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Whole eye ball with a portion of the optic nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Tissue retrieval by enucleation from cadavers includes removal of the entire eye ball along with a portion of the optic nerve.

 

Ref: pg 308/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for eye donation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS for eye donation include:

 

  • Death from unknown cause
  • Infections like: HIV, Syphilis, TB, congenital rubella, viral hepatitis
  • Creutzfeldt Jacob disease, SSPE etc.
  • Recipient of transplanted organ, etc

 

Ref: pg 241/ corneal & refractive surgery/ Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition.

choices.text: Eyes can be removed from a living human being with consent.
Optic atrophy in recipient is a contraindication
Donated eyes can never be sold or bought.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding eye donation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eyes can be removed from a living human being with consent.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anyone of any age can pledge to donate eyes after death.

  • Donated eyes can never be bought or sold.

  • Eyes CANNOT be removed from a living human being inspite of his/her consent & wish.

  • Contraindications for eye donation include transmissible diseases like â€“ HIV, HBsAg, syphilis, TB etc.

  • Recipients with only anterior segment diseases are eligible for corneal transplantation, and should have a normal posterior segment.

questions.text: What is the sample used for the screening of HIV, Syphilis, HBsAg and Anti-HCV in an eye donor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the time of eye retrieval , blood sample is collected from the cadaver and sent for screening infections like- HIV, HBsAg, Syphilis etc.

 

Ref: Pg 560/ Eye banking/ PEYMAN’S principle & practise of ophthalmology/ 2nd edition

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of short-term storage after eye ball retrieval?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moist chamber storage

 

Option B.

 

Whole globe is sealed in a container and stored at 4 degree C.

 

Short-term (upto 48 hours) = Moist chamber storage

 

 

Intermediate (2 weeks) = MK medium, optisol

 

Long-term (35 days) = Organ culture method, cryopreservation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MK Medium (McCarey-Kaufman Medium): This is a medium used for the storage of corneal tissues. However, MK medium is typically used for short-term preservation of up to 4 days. It's often used in scenarios where corneal transplantation is planned shortly after retrieval.

 

 

Option C. Cryopreservation: This method involves freezing the tissue for long-term storage. Cryopreservation is not commonly used for corneal storage due to the risk of damaging the corneal endothelial cells during the freeze-thaw process.

 

Option D. Organ Culture Method: This is a method used for longer-term storage of corneal tissues, allowing storage for up to 4 weeks. It involves keeping the cornea in a special nutrient medium at a controlled temperature, which is higher than that used in MK medium or moist chamber storage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Moist chamber storage is a method used for the short-term storage of corneal tissue after eyeball retrieval, suitable for maintaining the viability of the cornea for up to 24-48 hours.

 

Ref: pg 137/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Who established the first eye bank in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Res muthiah

 

Explanation:

 

The first eye bank establishment and 1st cornea transplantation in INDIA was done by late DR. RES MUTHIAH in the year 1948.

 

Ref: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10643183

questions.text: When was NPCB established in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1976

 

Explanation

 

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) was launched in India in 1976 with the goal of reducing the prevalence of blindness through comprehensive eye care services and improving accessibility to eye care facilities across the country. This program has been pivotal in addressing various eye-related issues and enhancing the quality of life for many individuals.

 

Key aspects of the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) include:

 

  1. Focus on Preventable Blindness: A significant emphasis is placed on preventing blindness caused by conditions that are easily treatable, such as cataract, which is the leading cause of blindness in India.
  2. Community Participation: The program encourages community involvement and utilizes a decentralized approach, engaging primary health centers and local healthcare workers to maximize its outreach and impact.
  3. Capacity Building: It aims to strengthen the infrastructure for eye care services by upgrading existing facilities, providing training to eye care professionals, and increasing the availability of specialized equipment and materials.
  4. Partnerships: The NPCB collaborates with various governmental and non-governmental organizations, including international agencies, to pool resources, share expertise, and expand its reach and effectiveness.
  5. Monitoring and Evaluation: Regular monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are in place to assess the program's performance, identify areas for improvement, and ensure the achievement of its targets.

 

Ref: Pg 480/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: According to NPCB,a visual acuity below which of the following levels is classified as blindness?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3/60

 

Explanation:

 

NPCB definition of blindness:

 

Presenting visual acuity < 3/60 or counting fingers at 3 metres or central visual field less than 10 degree in better eye.

 

Old definition: Visual acuity less than 6/60 or central field less than 20 degree in better eye.

 

Ref: pg 476/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: What is the visual acuity below which it is termed as low vision according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6/18

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to WHO, a visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye is defined as low vision.

 

Ref: Page no. 444/ Chapter 20/ Community Ophthalmology/ Ed. 4/ AK Khurana Comprehensive ophthalmology

questions.text: According to WHO, a visual acuity of less than what value is defined as a criterion for blindness?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3/60

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO in 1972 proposed a uniform criterion. “Visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent.

 

Ref: pg 475/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: The following are the major blinding eye conditions for immediate attention to achieve the goals of VISION 2020, by WHO, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glaucoma

 

WHO identified 5 major blinding eye condition for immediate action:

 

  • Cataract
  • Childhood blindness
  • Trachoma
  • Refractive errors
  • Oncocerchiasis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glaucoma is not one of the primary goals of Vision 2020 initiative.

 

Ref: pg 478/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

Pizzarello L, Abiose A, Ffytche T, et al. VISION 2020: The Right to Sight: A Global Initiative to Eliminate Avoidable Blindness. Arch Ophthalmol. 2004;122(4):615–620. doi:10.1001/archopht.122.4.615

questions.text: What is the commonest cause of blindness in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital cataract

 

Refractive error would cause vision impairment not blindness

 

Cataract would cause blindness
 

 

Refractive errors are the commonest cause of visual impairment in children.

 

Others: 

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency

  • Measles

  • Congenital cataract

  • Retinopathy of prematurity

  • Childhood glaucoma

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin A Deficiency: This used to be one of the leading causes of preventable blindness in children, especially in developing countries. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to xerophthalmia and keratomalacia, resulting in severe visual impairment or blindness. However, with improved nutrition and supplementation programs, its prevalence has significantly decreased in many parts of the world.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This is a significant cause of visual impairment and treatable blindness in children. Congenital cataracts can be isolated or part of systemic syndromes, and early detection and surgical intervention are crucial for visual development.

 

Option C. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP): ROP is a disease of the eye affecting prematurely born babies. It's related to the use of supplemental oxygen in the neonatal period. ROP can lead to blindness but is preventable with proper screening and timely treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While vitamin A deficiency, congenital cataract, and retinopathy of prematurity are significant causes of childhood blindness, refractive errors are currently recognized as the most common cause of visual impairment in children due to their high prevalence and frequent lack of correction.

 

Ref: pg 483/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: According to the strategic plan for VISION 2020, glaucoma screening is done for all persons above the age of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 35

 

VISION 2020 recommends opportunistic glaucoma screening at eye care institutions in all persons

 

  • Above the age of 35
  • Those with diabetes mellitus
  • Family history of glaucoma

 

Ref: pg 484/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Annually, when is the eye donation fortnight organised?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) August 25 to September 8

Under NPCB, eye donation fortnight is organised from 25th August to 8th September every year to promote eye donation.

 

Ref: pg 485/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: An operating eye surgeon should not perform more than how many surgeries in a day at an eye camp according to VISION 2020?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) >50

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideally the number of operations performed per day by a surgeon should not exceed 50 and in a camp should not exceed 200 to maintain quality of surgery.

 

Ref: pg 487 / systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

choices.text: Presently SICS & phacoemulsification techniques are recommended
At least 5 operating surgeons should be present
Both the eyes should never be operated at one go
Cases with surgical risks such as diabetes, hypertensives & cardiac problems should not be operated in camps

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the guidelines laid down by the government of India for organising eye camps?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) At least 5 operating surgeons should be present

 

Option B.

 

  • At least 1, preferably 2 operating surgeons should perform cataract surgeries.

  • Presently both SICS & PHACOEMULSIFICATION techniques are performed.

  • Both eyes should never be operated at one go.

  • Cases with associated risk factors should be referred to base hospitals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presently SICS & Phacoemulsification Techniques are Recommended: Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) and Phacoemulsification are modern and efficient techniques for cataract surgery. These methods are indeed recommended for their safety, effectiveness, and relatively quick recovery times.

 

Option C. Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go: This is a standard guideline in eye care, especially in camp settings. Operating on both eyes simultaneously increases the risk of complications, including infection. Therefore, it is recommended to operate on one eye at a time.

 

Option D. Cases with Surgical Risks Such as Diabetes, Hypertensives & Cardiac Problems Should Not be Operated in Camps: This statement is generally true. Patients with systemic conditions like diabetes, hypertension, or cardiac problems are at a higher risk of complications during and after surgery. Such cases typically require more comprehensive pre-operative and post-operative care than what might be available at an eye camp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the requirement of having at least 5 operating surgeons at eye camps is not a standardized guideline by the Government of India, unlike the recommendations for SICS & Phacoemulsification techniques, the practice of not operating on both eyes simultaneously, and the avoidance of operating on high-risk patients in camp settings.

 

Ref: pg 487/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a low vision aid (LVA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toric iol

 

Option C:

 

Low vision aids are optical devices used to improve the residual vision in visually handicapped individuals.

 

Eg: Hand held magnifiers

 

Telescopes – Galilean, Kepler

 

High plus spectacles

 

Video magnifier systems

 

 TORIC IOL are used to correct astigmatism along with cataract surgery.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Keplerian Telescope: This is a type of telescopic device used as a low vision aid. It's designed to help people with low vision see objects at a distance, like street signs or bus numbers.

 

 

 

Option B. High Plus Spectacles: These are spectacles with high magnification lenses. They are used as low vision aids to help people with poor vision to read or perform other close-up tasks.

 

 

Option D. Video Magnifier System: This is a device that uses a camera to display enlarged images on a screen. It's a common low vision aid used for reading and viewing detailed objects.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that TORIC IOLs, while used in eye surgery to correct astigmatism, are not classified as low vision aids (LVAs), unlike devices like Keplerian telescopes, high plus spectacles, and video magnifier systems that are specifically designed to assist those with low vision.

 

Ref: pg 354/ theory and practise of optics and refraction/4th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Use of all the following agents enhances the bioavailabiltity of drugs in the eye, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium chloride

 

Optino C:

 

Bioavailability of drug in the eye is enhanced by use of viscous vehicles like:

 

  • Hydroxypropyl methyl cellulose
  • Polyvinyl alcohol
  • Polyvinyl pyrrolidone
  • Hyaluronic acid

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hydroxypropyl Methylcellulose (HPMC): This is a viscoelastic polymer used as a viscosity-enhancing agent in eye drops. It increases the retention time of the drug on the eye's surface, thus enhancing bioavailability.

 

Option B. Hyaluronic Acid: Often used in ophthalmic formulations, hyaluronic acid has viscoelastic properties that can increase the contact time of the drug with the ocular surface, thereby enhancing drug absorption and bioavailability.

 

Option D. Polyvinyl Alcohol: This is another viscosity-enhancing agent used in ophthalmic preparations. It helps in prolonging the contact time of the drug on the ocular surface, thereby improving drug bioavailability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium Chloride is used for tonicity adjustment in ophthalmic solutions. It does not enhance the bioavailability of drugs in the eye, unlike viscosity-enhancing agents like Hydroxypropyl Methylcellulose, Hyaluronic Acid, and Polyvinyl Alcohol.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 146

questions.text: Which of the following solutions has the greatest anti-inflammatory action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1% Prednisolone acetate

 

Option D:

 

The anti-inflammatory action of steroids – from high to low:

 

Topical ophthalmic steroids placed in descending order of potency:

 

  • Difluprednate ophthalmic emulsion 0.05%w/v(most potent)
  • Prednisolone Acetate 1%
  • Dexamethasone 0.1%
  • Betamethasone 0.1%
  • Prednisolone Sodium Phosphate 0.5%
  • Fluorometholone 0.1% (least potent)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 0.1% Dexamethasone Acetate: Dexamethasone is a potent corticosteroid. It is highly effective in reducing inflammation and is commonly used in ophthalmology for its strong anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Option B. 0.1% Fluorometholone: Fluorometholone is less potent compared to dexamethasone and prednisolone. It is often used for inflammatory conditions of the eye where the risk of steroid-induced intraocular pressure (IOP) increase is a concern.

 

Option C. 1% Medroxyprogesterone: This is a synthetic progestin and is not typically known for strong anti-inflammatory effects in ophthalmic use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that 1% Prednisolone Acetate, due to its high potency and concentration, is likely the most effective among the listed options for providing strong anti-inflammatory action in ophthalmic use.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION page 154

2. https://www.formularywkccgmtw.co.uk/therapeutic-sections/eye/inflammatory-eye-conditions/corticosteroids-and-the-eye/

questions.text: Which of the following beta blockers is known to increase the perfusion of optic nerve head?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Betaxolol

 

Option D:

 

  • Betaxolol is the only beta-1 specific beta blocker.
  • It is believed to increase the perfusion of the optic nerve head.
  • Confers neuroprotection.
  • It is associated with fewer pulmonary side effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Timolol: A non-selective beta blocker widely used in the treatment of glaucoma. While effective in lowering intraocular pressure, it does not have a significant effect on increasing optic nerve head perfusion.

 

Option B. Carteolol: Another non-selective beta blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity. It lowers intraocular pressure but does not specifically increase optic nerve head perfusion.

 

Option C. Levobunolol: Similar to Timolol, Levobunolol is a non-selective beta blocker used for lowering intraocular pressure. It is not known to significantly affect optic nerve head perfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Due to its beta – 1 blocker selectivity, Betaxolol has a lesser effect on pulmonary and vascular beta-2 receptors. It is known to potentially increase blood flow to the optic nerve head, which could be beneficial in glaucoma patients where optic nerve head perfusion is a concern.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 157

questions.text: Which of the following preservatives is the most epitheliotoxic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Benzalkonium chloride

 

Opiton C:

 

  • Preservatives in standard commercial preparations are epitheliotoxic to the cornea and conjunctiva if used very frequently.
  •  Benzalkonium chloride is the most epitheliotoxic.
  • Povidone and Chlorobutanol are better tolerated.
  • Some newer preservatives such as sodium perborate and purite disintegrate into harmless molecules on contact with the eye and exposure to light.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Povidone: Often used as a lubricant in artificial tears, povidone is generally gentle on the epithelial cells of the eye. It's less likely to cause irritation or damage to the surface of the eye compared to some other preservatives.

 

Option B. Chlorobutanol: This preservative is known for its mildness and is less irritating to the ocular surface. However, it is less commonly used due to its limited antimicrobial efficacy and stability issues in certain formulations.

 

Option D. Sodium Perborate: This is a preservative that decomposes into water and oxygen upon contact with the eye, making it much gentler on the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benalkonium Chloride is the more epitheliotoxic preservative agent. This is a common preservative in ophthalmic solutions but is known for its cytotoxic effects on the corneal and conjunctival epithelial cells. It can disrupt the tear film and cause ocular surface disease with long-term use.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 158
